summary: four Zika cases have been confirmed in Zhejiang, china. rapid assessment of people’s knowledge, attitudes, and practices is crucial to its prevention and control. web-based surveys to assess public KAP regarding Zika may be a growing trend. participants completing the Internet-based survey were more likely to know the transmission route of Zika (odds ratio [OR]=5.0, 95% CI 3.0-8.0), and that pregnant women were at high risk for Zika (OR 5.5, 95% CI 3.5-8.4) than those completing the paper-based survey. the government should ensure sufficient access to health information for the elderly and less educated people in the community to improve health equity. hejiang exports 65% of its products to over 215 countries and regions. hejiang has a hot, humid climate in summer, making it a suitable habitat for the Aedes species. inaccurate information and negative attitudes may lead to unnecessary concerns, rumors, and even panic. the questionnaire collected sociodemographic data (sex, age, occupation, education level, and residential area); and sources of information on Zika. questions about attitudes to Zika were based on the latest official report of world health organization and literature. study was approved by the ethics committee at Zhejiang CDC. informed consent was obtained from all participants before information was collected. participants who were able to correctly answer questions about transmission of Zika were coded into the high-KAP category. the questionnaire was designed by the Zhejiang Provincial Center for Disease Control and Prevention (Zhejiang CDC) it collected sociodemographic data (sex, age, occupation, education level, and residential area); and sources of information on Zika. questions about attitudes to Zika were based on the latest official report of world health organization and literature. the questionnaire was hosted on wenjuan a large free questionnaire platform. participants recruited from among community residents at Yiwu and Hangzhou. the first four Zika cases were found in the two cities in Zhejiang province. the association between sociodemographic variables and KAP variables was analyzed separately. participants who were able to correctly answer the knowledge-based questions about transmission of Zika, main at-risk population, adverse outcomes of Zika during pregnancy, and mosquitoes were extremely common were coded into the high-KAP category. 91.1% (566/621) had a postsecondary education level. the proportion of participants who worked in government institutions, as farmers, and other occupation groups (eg, retired, housewife, househusband, and unemployed) were 11.4% (51/447), 31.1% (139/447), 15.4% (69/447), and 42.1% (188/447), respectively. 423.5 (2).001 Secondary (9-12 years) 111 (24.8) 40 (6.5) 151 (14.14) Postsecondary (>12 years) 142 (31.8) 566 (91.1) 708 (66.29) Occupation Staff of government institution 51 (11.4) 451 (72.6) 502 (47.00) 413.7 (3).001 Staff of business or service industry 139 (31.1) 71 (11.4) 210 (19.66) Farmer 69 (15.4) 3 (0.5) 72 (6.74) mosquitoes were extremely common in dark, wet places such as river banks and parks. this group was made up of 98.4% (611/621) and 99.5% (445/447) of participants completing the Internet-based and paper-based surveys. a statistically significant difference (22=684.9, P.001; Internet-recruited participants were less likely to know this than community-recruited participants. Internet-recruited participants were more likely to seek information regarding Zika than community-recruited participants. only the source of participants was found to be associated with the practice of actively seeking information. Potential harm due to contracting Zika was thought to be serious, mild, and nil by 31.39%. practices Regarding Zika Among the total participants, 98.50% (1052/1068) carried out preventive strategies such as using a mosquito net or mosquito repellent. there was no significant difference between participants completing the Internet-based survey and the paper-based survey. 1056 (98.88%) knew that mosquitoes were extremely common in dark, wet places such as river banks and parks. this group was made up of 98.4% (611/621) and 99.5% (445/447) of participants completing the Internet-based and paper-based surveys, respectively, which was a statistically significant difference. 1068 of total participants, 502 (47.00%) were worried about contracting Zika. there was no difference between the two groups (22=90.7, P=.60; Table 2). there was no significant difference in practices between participants completing the Internet-based survey and the paper-based survey (21=2.8, P=.09) there was a significant difference between the two participants regarding seeking out information about Zika (21=90.7, P.001). the total expenditure for paper-based investigation was 20,115 RMB. participants in the Internet-based survey had a higher level of basic knowledge than participants in the paper-based survey. the Internet-based survey required fewer resources and was much faster than the paper-based survey. participants in the Web-based study had characteristics different from those in the paper-based study. study found no difference in sex distribution between the two groups. but both groups had more female than male participants. this might be because women are more concerned about their health than men. study found that 98.50% of participants carried out strategies to prevent mosquito bites at home. this suggests that the public of Zhejiang have positive behaviors toward preventing mosquito-borne diseases. this suggests that the public of Zhejiang have positive behaviors toward preventing mosquito-borne diseases. the internet-based survey involved fewer resources and was much faster than the paper-based survey in the community. if only an Internet-based survey were used to carry out emergency assessments of health education needs, you would need to be cautious about the results. over 90% (566/621, 91.1%) of the Internet-recruited participants had postsecondary education compared with 31.8% (142/447) of community-recruited participants. occupational distribution comparisons also found a significant difference between the two groups. participants in the web-based survey had a higher level of knowledge about Zika than participants in the paper-based survey. this might be because of having more young and well-educated participants in the web-based survey. health information should be communicated through official channels as much as possible, to minimize the flow of inaccurate information and rumors. limitations This study has some limitations: first, selection bias might exist. data for the paper-based study were collected in the community during the daytime.
